comment: So this black hole is something of a star mangling hammer?
Cool fact planets also have sound theres videos on that aswell.

When black holes or neutron stars collide, they produce pretty strong gravitational waves, and if you somehow stood close enough, you would hear them. You would also immediately become a diffuse mass of unrecognizable and likely exotic matter, because you stood, in astronomical terms, right next to a supernova-scale catastrophic event. Would not recommend.

I remember seeing this movie before called Time Trap. They are stuck in a cave where time varies in different parts of the cave. A really good well thought out logical movie. Give it a watch, reading your comment reminded me of that movie.
Source for those interested: Relatively speaking: relativity, black holes, and the fate of the universe by Chaisson, Eric page 213 (super interesting and somewhat easy to understand book)
